conclusion: Identify the forces and components acting on the hemispheres.
Hemispheres are in contact with vertical walls; friction between hemisphere A and the left wall; hemisphere B is smooth; angle between line connecting centers and horizontal is 30°.
Draw free-body diagrams for hemispheres A and B.
For hemisphere B: vertical force is 2mg downward, horizontal force is normal force NB from the wall.
For hemisphere A: vertical force is mg downward and friction force f upward, horizontal force is normal force NA from the wall.
Assume static equilibrium; sum of forces in horizontal and vertical directions must be zero.
Determine components of normal forces and friction for hemispheres A and B.
For hemisphere B: NB sin(30°) = 2mg and NB cos(30°) = NA.
For hemisphere A: NA sin(30°) = mg + f and NA cos(30°) = NB.
Solve NB sin(30°) = 2mg to find NB = 4mg.
Solve NA = NB cos(30°) to find NA = 2√3mg.
Solve NA sin(30°) = mg + f to find f = (√3 - 1)mg.
Relate static friction f to sliding friction force: f = μNA.
Substitute values for f and NA to find μ = (√3 - 1)/(2√3).
Final answer: dynamic friction factor between hemisphere A and the left wall is (3 - √3)/6.
